children.subject: For master, it's usually just MS Computer Science, not machine learning specifically. There is MSML at CMU, but it's also industry oriented.
Why do you want external programs? Just curious...

Grad school essays aren't like essays for undergrad: most applications will include a statement of purpose which mainly is just a "why do you think you should go to grad school in this area and at our institution?" and you should probably talk about your personal experiences within the field. Sometimes schools will ask for a personal statement or some variant of it, which is to describe your background but often its to highlight any sort of disadvantages you might have faced while pursuing your studies. A few programs will ask for which professors you want to work with and why or select professors you are interested in working with (although this is less common for masters programs I think). 

Check out: https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~harchol/gradschooltalk.pdf for more details about applying to PhD programs.

A note about applying to PhD and then mastering out: PhD programs at top universities are much harder to get into than their respective masters. Some schools will only let you apply to one, some will let you be considered for masters programs, and others will let you apply to multiple so be careful about this. If your intention is to get into a PhD program such that you don't need to pay for a masters I'd reconsider, especially if you want to go to a good university. For ML at Berkeley, the admission numbers I've heard from a prof was 3000 applicants for 40 positions in the PhD program (I think) from a few years ago so its very competitive.

history.content:
I am a rising junior who is preparing to apply for competitive external masters programs. I was wondering where/who is the best place to go to for help for advice on planning junior year with respect to activities or what are some good resources to consult to direct any planning questions. I was also wondering what the essay process is like/who to go to for help for planning this. My plan is to open the applications when they come out this fall and see what types of essay questions there are. What is the best way to organize now as a junior? Also is it appropriate to reach out to admissions coordinators per @4482 for personal advice? 

I'm starting to think of letters of recommendation and was wondering what is the best way to get the attention of professors now so that I could have solid recs by the time I apply during senior year (besides who I research with, which will count as 1 rec). I have a good research background and am anticipating that I will want to move to an EECS lab during junior year. I also have a good internship at a faang but I heard that its probably strongly preferable to get recs from eecs faculty.

Finally I was wondering how competitive admissions can get for masters/graduate programs if I'm interested in ML (I'm also thinking of taking a master out of PhD program; although I do research now I don't know if I will fully commit to a PhD). Is there a place to review any relevant stats and gauge how good my application is?
history.subject: Preparing for masters/grad admissions
